Ginette buys her products in one of Benin's cities. To bolster her business, she joins the other members of the Gbenonkpo group in seeking a third loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: buy plastic items and plastic bags

loans.name: Ankato Allama Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  ANKATO ALLAMA  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  31ans, 3 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles monogamiques à KOLONDIEBA, une des Sous-préfecture de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités à tout moment. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution.
Mme   SARATA (1ère à gauche sur la photo) compte acheter avec son prêt des condiments pour ensuite les revendre à Zantoumala et en famille. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 500FCFA.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the Ankato Allama group are married women who on average are 31 years old with three children, all living in monogamous families in Kolondiéba, a sub-prefecture of the third administrative region of Mali.

They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution so they can carry out their activities at any time of year. They are on their fourth loan with the institution.

Ms. Sarata (first on the left in the photo) plans to use the loan to buy condiments for resale in Zantoumala and within her family.

She expects to achieve an average monthly profit of 15,500 CFA francs. These profits will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with daily expenditures.

loans.use: buy condiments

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Né en 1972 à FAKOLA -Ville, (3ème Région administrative du Mali), BOUBACAR  y réside avec son enfant et sa femme dans une famille traditionnelle chez ses parents.
 Mr BOUBACAR s’est vite intéressé à la couture après avoir quitté l’école prématurément. Aujourd’hui il dispose d’un atelier de couture combiné avec un étalage de mercerie au bord de la route dans leur concession  où il coud et vend ses articles. Il est très sollicité dans la ville  et surtout le jour de foire. 
Fort de ses 6 années d’expériences dans le domaine, il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  deuxième prêt. 
BOUBACAR compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des matériels de couture (mercerie) et  tissus. Il s’approvisionne chez les grossistes à BAMAKO et en Côte D’IVOIRE. Il effectue ses ventes au comptant et quelques fois à crédit  à une clientèle mixte.
BOUBACAR espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
Born in 1972 in Fakola City (third administrative region of Mali), Boubacar resides with his wife and child in a traditional family along with his parents.

Mr Boubacar became interested in sewing soon after he left school prematurely. Today he has a combination sewing workshop and haberdashery store along the road at his concession, where he sews and sells his products. He is very much in demand in the city and especially on market days.

With six years' experience in the field, he collaborates with Soro Yiriwaso to increase his working capital and satisfy an increasing number of customers. He is on his second loan.

Boubacar intends to use the loan to buy sewing materials (haberdashery items) and fabrics. He buys from wholesalers in Bamako and from Cote d'Ivoire. He sells for cash and sometimes on credit to a mixed clientele.

Boubacar hopes to make monthly profits of 100,000 CFA francs that will be used to support the family, repay the loan and for reinvestment in the business.

loans.use: Purchase sewing materials (haberdashery items), fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy solar lamps that they will sell in their communities

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    DANAYA est constitué de 7 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de34 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  NIEBALA de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 3éme prêt. Les 2 précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  de grains à l’image de SIATA BOUGOU qui est la 1ére femme de la gauche vers la droite  dans la photo. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 1,5 tonne de maïs avec les paysans producteurs. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The Danaya Group is made up of 7 married women, who have an average age of 34 years and an average of 4 children.  They live in traditional extended families in the Niebala area of Bougouni town.   They know one another through family, business and local ties.  The women joined the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to strengthen their financial position and improve their businesses.  This will be their third loan with the organisation, the previous two loans have been fully repaid.  

This group of women all buy and sell grain, as does Siata Bougou (the woman standing on the far left of the photo).  Siata Bougou will use her loan to buy 1.5 tonnes of maize from small producers.  She sells her product from home and at the market.  Her customers are usually women and she sells to them for cash and on credit.  She expects to earn a monthly average of 25,000 francs CFA and she will use her earnings to repay the loan and invest in her business.

loans.use: to buy cereal grains.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
Tomas y su esposa son productores de leche la cual vende a una de las empresas recolectoras de la ciudsad de La Paz;  vive en casa propia, tienen dos hijos, los cuales están en edad escolar, en la comunidad Irama Belén del municipio de Achacachi, a dos horas y media de viaje de la ciudad de La Paz, cuenta con pocas cabezas de ganado  las cuales le proporcionan leche.

El crédito lo requiere para compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar su producción de leche y sus ingresos para su familia.

El sueño de Tomas es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado, aumentando la producción  de leche en su comunidad.

Es la primera vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la primera vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Tomas and his wife produce milk which they sell to one of the collection companies from the city of La Paz. He lives in his own house in the community of Irama Belén in the municipality of Achacachi, two and a half hours' journey from the city of la Paz. They have two children who are school age. Tomas has a few heads of cattle which provide him with milk.

He needs the loan to buy a dairy cow so he can increase his milk production and his income for the family.

Tomas's dream is to increase his number of animals, increasing the milk production in his community. This is the first time he has asked for a loan with IMPRO and the first time with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow to increase his volume of milk production in order to improve his income.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen lives and works outside of Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. Originally dominated by English settlers in the early 20th century, the region’s farmland was redistributed after independence. This left Trans-Nzoia, one of Kenya’s most cosmopolitan areas, with individuals from a variety of linguistic and ethnic groups living in close proximity. 

The lush soil of the region ensures that farmers can grow a variety of crops, including maize, sunflower, sugar cane, millet, and beans. Kitale is located near Mount Elgon, East Africa's oldest and largest solitary extinct volcano, whose substantial forest cover makes Kitale a high-potential beekeeping region. 

Stephen is married and has five children. Him and his wife both farm and are currently growing maize and tending to livestock. Stephen is excited to start beekeeping because it is a low-labour activity that will let him focus on his farming. 

This is Stephen’s first loan, and he plans to use the income from his beehives for his family’s development.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in western Kenya and is famous for its rainforest. Many farmers in the area grow maize, sugar cane and bananas, with maize being the primary crop. The density of the old growth trees in the Kakamega forest, and the variety of crops grown in the area, make this an excellent area for beekeeping. 

Aggrey is married and has four children. His wife works as a businesslady, while he farms their land. He has been farming for seventeen years and is currently growing maize, vegetable and fruits. Aggrey is excited to become a beekeeper because “I love honey as medicine and it has a good income.”

This is Aggrey’s first loan with Kiva and he plans to use the income from his beehives to buy even more hives and invest in beekeeping. Aggrey’s dream is to “own a big farm and do more farming.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production

loans.name: Avec-Mali

texts.en: Watch a video to learn more about AVEC-Mali! AVEC-Mali is a women’s association based in Mopti, Mali with 74 members. The association engages in a variety of activities, such as selling clean cookstoves, teaching women to read and write and educating women about family planning. In July, nine women from the association starting selling solar lamps (seven of them are featured in the photo). As of the end of September they sold 1,200 lamps and they have ambitious plans to grow the sales. Korotoumou (fourth from the left) is one of nine members of AVEC-Mali who sell solar lamps. She is 47 years old and has six children. In addition to her work with the women’s association, Korotoumou is the matron at a health center in Mopti, and she sells grains. In July, she started selling solar lamps to fisherman, students and farmers, who are reliant on kerosene and flashlights for light. With a solar lamp, her customers can save money. Kerosene and mobile phone charging currently cost about $110 per year; whereas, a solar lamp costs $25 and has a lifetime of about five years. These solar lamps provide 8 hours of light and can charge a mobile phone. On top of being less expensive, solar lamps are more durable and reliable and keep people from stealing mobile phones. “With a solar lamp, you don’t have to go to a mobile phone charging station and give your phone to someone who may steal your phone or use the call credit you have on your phone,” says Korotoumou. Selling solar lamps provides income for the women and for the association. The women earn $2 for every lamp they sell and the association earns $3. The money the association earns is invested in a warehouse to store solar lamp inventory and motorcycles to distribute the products. The solar saleswomen are well organized – each responsible for her own sales territory. They educate their communities about the benefits of solar lights and generate lamp sales through group meetings and demonstrations at night. Since customers cannot afford to pay for the lamps up front, the women need working capital. A Kiva loan will allow the solar saleswomen to obtain solar lamp inventory from NOTS Lampe Solaire on credit. When they receive payment from their customers they will re-pay the Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy solar lamps that they will sell in their communities

loans.name: Yolbin

texts.es: Gracias por apoyar a Yolbin, quien con su credikiva compró mucha mercancia, especialmente ropa y calzado, que llegó promovida por su catalogo. Con su credikiva, pudo obtener un mayor capital de trabajo, y vendió mediante la forma  pre-pago. Su negocio ahora posee mas clientes y ella logró ampliar el tiempo que da a su clientela para pagar; hoy posee mas ingresos, para continuar mejorando su calidad de vida. En la actualidad Yolbin está aplicando a un credikiva, mediante el cual comprará ropa, encargada y cumplirá con la solicitud de la temporada, que usualmente impacta positivamente sus ventas, haciendo de su  credikiva una inversón exitosa.  Ella dice a sus finaciadores: " Doy Gracias por los beneficios brindados, el crédito ha sido pieza fundacmental para mejorara mi calidad de vida".
texts.en:
Thank you for supporting Yolbin, who used her Kiva loan to buy a lot of merchandise, especially clothing and footwear, which was promoted via her catalogue. With her Kiva loan she was able to have a larger working capital and sold via the pre-payment method. Her business now has more customers and she was able to extend the time she gives her customers to pay. Now she has a better income, so she can carry on improving her quality of life.

Currently Yolbin is asking for a Kiva loan which she will use to buy clothing which has been ordered and will be able to meet the seasonal orders. These normally impact positively on her sales, making her Kiva loan a successful investment. She says to her lenders:" Thank you for providing these benefits, the loan has been the essential key to improving my quality of life".

loans.use: to buy stock which has been ordered.

loans.name: Farida

texts.ru: Фарида кредитуется в ИМОНе повторно. Она честная и трудолюбивая женщина. Фариде 25 лет. Она разведена и сама воспитывает свою дочь. Она уже несколько лет занимается собственным бизнесом. Она занимается купле продажей молочных продуктов. Фарида покупает молоко, кефир с других районов оптом и реализует в розницу на местном рынке. Фарида является основной кормилицей семьи. Ее мать занимается предоставлением услуги швеи, а отец является сварщиком. Фарида хочет увеличить свой оборотный капитал таким образом получить больше дохода. Она хочет, чтобы ее сын вырос в достатке и получил хорошее образование. Она запрашивает займ на сумму 3000 сомони для покупки молочных продуктов. Она ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en: Farida is taking out a loan at IMON for the second time. She is an honest and hard working woman. She is 25 years old. She is divorced and is raising a daughter by herself. Farida has been doing own business for several years. She buys and sells dairy products. Farida buys milk and buttermilk from other regions in wholesale and sells it in retail at her local market. Farida is the main provider in the family. Her mother provides sewing services and her father is a welder. Farida wants to increase her working capital and by that get more profit. She wants for her daughter to grow up in prosperity and get a good education. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 3,000 somoni to buy dairy products. She is waiting for your generosity and hopes for your kindness.

loans.use: to buy dairy products to increase working capital.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.ru: Ахмаду 53 года, женат и имеет пятерых детей. Он является мастером на все руки. Ахмад одновременно занимается животноводством, растениеводством, садоводством и понемногу делает ремонты в своем районе Хуросон. Ахмад сейчас в хозяйстве имеет 3 барашек и одну корову. Все его деятельности, кроме животноводства являются сезонными. Поэтому Ахмад просит кредит, чтобы купить пару барашек, и увеличить поголовье скота. У него 20-летний опыт в этой сфере деятельности и с животными он справляется на отлично.
texts.en: Ahmad is 53 years old, married and has five children. He is a good handyman. Ahmad does animal husbandry, field crop cultivation, horticulture and sometimes also does repairs in his region of Khuroson. Right now Ahmad has three sheep and one cow. All of his businesses besides livestock are seasonal. This is why Ahmad is asking for a loan to buy some sheep to increase the headcount of livestock. He has a twenty year experience in this field does a great job at keeping livestock.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his college tuition.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 39-year-old Martha from Kandehtown Bo. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 5 years and 18 years. One of her children is currently attending school. She began this business because she wanted to help her husband educate their children. Martha runs a general stock business where she sells soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business throughout the week for 10 hours per day. Martha says that her business is doing well.
Martha has requested a loan in order to purchase soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, Martha plans to expand her enterprise even more. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Liliy

texts.en:
Lily is 27 years old and single with one child. She runs a beauty salon, and she has been in this business for three years with a monthly income from the business of KES 89,140. She is borrowing a loan of KES 100,000, which she intends to use to purchase business assets especially salon electronics especially  driers and blow driers. This will ensure efficiency by eliminating salon queue and ascertaining quick services.

Lily plans to expand her salon even further with more assets with the anticipated profits. This is her third loan and her hope and dream is to have a self-sustaining business.

loans.use: To purchase business assets especially salon electronics like driers and blowdriers

loans.name: 12 De Junio Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “12 DE JUNIO” iniciará el tercer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Senkata, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Dora es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de ropa, venta de abarrotes, tejido de mantas, venta de juguetes, taller de carpintería, venta de zapatos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Dora es integrante, ella indica que hace tres años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una asesora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de taller de costura de ropa; da a conocer que este negocio fue heredado por sus padres hace varios años atrás, es por ello que ella sigue el negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de tela) que adquirirá de las tiendas mayoristas de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a  la elaboración lo comercializará en otros departamentos de Bolivia. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener a su familia, ya que ella es soltera y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta los consultorios de salud que se tiene en la oficina.
texts.en:
Communal bank “12 de junio” is in its third cycle with Pro Mujer, in the satellite office of Senkata. It is composed of eight members and run by a board where Dora is the president. The members have different activities, such as selling clothes, selling groceries, weaving blankets, selling toys, carpentry and selling shoes.

This loan will be beneficial for small micro entrepreneurs such as Dora. She has been working with Pro Mujer for three years, invited by a representative from the institution that paid her a visit. She has a tailor’s shop, inherited from her parents some years ago.

The loan she is requesting will help her to increase her working capital. She will buy fabrics from the different wholesalers in the city of El Alto. She will make clothes and sell them in different regions in Bolivia. With this activity, she can maintain her family. She is single and has three children.

When asked what she likes the most about Pro Mujer, she says she likes the healthcare facilities.

loans.use: to buy fabrics.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is 39 years old and lives in Gardnerville, Liberia, which is one of the most populated area in the Montserrado County. Emma is married with four children between the ages of 8 years and 21 years, whom are in school and live at home. For ten years now, she has been selling used clothes in the community market. Emma started this business with the little amount she could afford and she learned this trade from her friends. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. She hopes to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Dorise

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 33 -year-old Dorise from Kandehtown Bo, Southern area in Freetown. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 5 years and 12 years.Two of her children are attending school. Dorise runs a cookery business; she sells cooked rice, fried fish and cool drinks. She has been running this business for the past 8 years. She wakes up at 4:30am to prepare her cookery business and she will not rest until the food is finished. One of her daughters usually helps her to run this cookery business. Her business is her only source of income. Dorise finds her major hardship as sometimes preparing the cooked food is very difficult. Dorise has requested a loan in order to purchase cooking items including bags of rice, coconut oil and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to change her cookery structure and pay her childrens school fees. In the future, she plans to have her own residence. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking items including bags of rice, coconut oil and pure water.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman aged 39 years old with five children all attending different schools. She lives in a rural setting with her family and her two nephews who lost their parents. She is the one who caters for their school fees. Mary is a farmer who deals in agriculture, where she grows passion fruits and tomatoes. She works six days in a week and each day, she works for eight hours. She also trades passion fruits as her side source of income. She started her business in 1990. Mary started this business in order to increase her family's income and she has acquired this loan to pay the school fees for her children. She said that she sells her products to traders from Kampala. Her future dream is to educate all her children to higher levels of education. Her biggest challenge is the unpredictable weather changes, for example, prolonged drought and at times too much rain. She describes herself as a hard working woman and she encourages lenders to continue helping farmers.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Dara

texts.en: Dara is a resident living in the Ponhea Leue district, Kandal province. She is 28 years old and married with a small child, who is attending local primary school at a low grade. She has a store in the village selling different kinds of beverages, including soft drinks and alcoholic drinks. She has run this business for almost one year now, and earns enough to provide for her family’s daily food. Dara is very thankful for the financial assistance extended to her in the previous loan cycle as she was able to improve her business and better her living conditions. She would like to apply for another 700 US dollars loan to increase her stock of beverages for a constant sale. She hopes that, through this loan, her sales will result in better profits. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and help her child in his education’s needs.

loans.use: to increase her stock of beverages for a constant sale.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is married, with six children and they are all in school.She sells charcoal on a retail basis. She takes care of an additional family member (mother). She has been in this business for three years. She works six days a week. She gets additional income from selling chapatti and fried cassava. 

Sauda has applied for a loan of UGX 700,000 (Uganda shillings) from Micro Credit for Development and Transformation SACCO (MCDT SACCO) to buy more bags of charcoal. Her major business challenges include seasonality (rainy season), which hinders her movements, and transportation. 

She aspires to get a van for transporting her charcoal and to build rental houses. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Torees Group

texts.en: Catherine, who is in her late 30s, is a single woman with a son who is in school. Since 1998, Catherine has been running a tailoring business. She is doing great in her business and starts working from 8.00 am to 6.00 pm each working day, and is able to make a good profit. This will be her sixth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to start a shop selling tailoring materials as well as buying one tailoring machine and more tailoring materials. Catherine managed to pay back all her previous loans successfully. She used her business profits to cover school fees and her household expenses. Catherine will use this new loan to buy additional tailoring materials. She dreams of opening a tailoring school. Catherine will share this loan with her loan  group "TOREES", which has a total of 3members. The members of this group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy additional tailoring materials.

loans.name: Nadzua

texts.en:
Nadzua is a potential maize seller who has been in the business for some time. She sells maize grains to earn a living out of the profits.
The previous loan helped her buy more maize grains for sale. Here again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy 6 sacks of maize grains for sale.

She appreciates for the support granted.

loans.use: to buy 6 sacks of maize grains for sale.

loans.name: Bintu

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 40-year-old Bintu from Torpoi town Bo, Southern area in Freetown. She is married with 5 children, between the ages of 1 year and 20 years. Four of her children are attending school. Bintu runs a fast food business - she sells gari salad, fried fish and cool drinks. She has been running this business for 10 years now. She starts preparing the food from 8:00am and she will not rest until the food is finished. Her business is her only source of income. Bintu describes her major hardship as business being difficult sometimes. Bintu has requested a loan in order to purchase cooking items including bags of gari, coconut oil and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her living conditions and pay her children's school fees. In the future, she plans to further expand her business. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking items including bags of gari, coconut oil and pure water.

loans.name: Salomie J.

texts.en: Salomie J. is 44 years old, married and lives at in Gardnerville of Montserrado County which is the commercial city of Liberia. She lives with her five children, who are aged between 20 and 30 years old, and whom are in school. She ended her education at the 8th grade. For the past five years, Salomie has been running a table market where she sells shortbread and soft drinks near the local market. She started this business with her husband's savings. She likes the way her customers buy from her and the profits she generates per day. Salomie is requesting a loan to purchase more flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and soft drinks for her business. In the near future, she wants to build a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is married with five children; four of her children go to school. She has one additional family member (sister). She operates a pub from home. She sells her goods to all kinds of people on retail and wholesale basis. She has been in this business for 5 years. She works seven days a week.

She has applied for a loan of Uganda Shillings 2,000,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy crates of beer, soda, local gin, and spirits. She is aspiring to build rental houses and own a fully stocked pub.

She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include paying school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, soda, local gin, and spirits for her pub.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is 42 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has 6 children, who are all currently in school. For the past 5 years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells sugar, soap and salt. To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food items for sale in her shop, thus helping Lydia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her shop's business. Lydia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lydia, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more food items for sale in her shop

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is a single mother of three children and two of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (her mother). She has a business of selling used clothes and has been in this business for 5 years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used clothes. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. She works at the market seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She is aspiring to become a wholesaler and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and not to piped water.  Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Mayimuna

texts.en: Mayimuna is widowed with seven children, six of whom go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells second hand shoes at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for two years. She works seven days a week.  She has applied for a loan of Uganda shillings 300,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy bales of second hand shoes.  She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. Her major business challenges include seasonality (rainy season), which hinders her movements, and transportation. She aspires to become a wholesaler and have a permanent business premise.  She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used shoes

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is married with five children, and three of her children go to school. She operates a pub on a retail basis. She takes care of additional family members(cousin). She has been in this business for 6 year. She works six days a week.

She has applied for a loan of Uganda Shillings 700,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more crates of beer, soda, and local brew. Her major business challenges include seasonality and electricity.

She aspires to own a fully stocked pub and get a permanent business premises. She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, soda, and local brew.
